The chapter on holy practices, starting from the beginning of the scroll, is the TathÄgata's next extensive answer to the question, refuting the previous four attachments.
The text is divided into three parts:
First, extensively refuting the attachment to permanence; second, briefly refuting happiness and purity; third, extensively refuting the attachment to the self and permanence.
The self is the beginning of attachment, so it is extensively refuted.
The first refutes permanence, which is divided into three parts:
First, clarifying the non-reasoning of externalists; second, clarifying their erroneous speech; third, correctly answering the question.
The first part is also divided into three:
First, clarifying the non-reasoning; second, citing the faults; third, concluding the non-reasoning.
The first part asks, why is it called non-reasoning?
It is a horizontal attachment to permanence.
Permanence is not produced by conditions, and what is produced by conditions is impermanent.
However, among the non-Buddhist teachings, some believe in spontaneity, which should not be produced by conditions.
If it is spontaneous, then the dharma dust (i.e., objects of cognition) corresponds to the intention (i.e., mind) and gives rise to this attachment. How could it not be produced by conditions?
Therefore, all non-Buddhist teachings are impermanent.

The old texts say:
In total there are three categories. Quoting the Brahma Practice Sutra, it says form phenomena, non-form phenomena, neither form nor non-form phenomena.
Taking neither form nor non-form as the category of non-action.
It also quotes the Holy Practice Sutra, saying After the white four karmas, one then attains, attaining non-action.
This meaning is not so. Neither form nor non-form is precisely the middle way of forgetting both and abandoning both. How can it be non-action;
Non-action and conditioned arising, this fault is not small.
Only after the fourfold white karman is one able to obtain it. This precept-receiving does not suffice to attest to the unconditioned of the middle way.
What is it?
Both conditioned and unconditioned are contaminated good dharmas. The icchantika believes in the conditioned but not in the unconditioned.
If one relies on the Hinayana, the unconditioned is contaminated;

if one relies on the present meaning, the unconditioned is uncontaminated. As previously cited, the precept-receiving of the holy conduct of precepts is unconditioned. What kind of unconditioned is it?
They rescue by saying:
If one does not allow the meaning of the unconditioned, then why is it said that the unconditioned is a dispute?
The answer:
The Sarvastivadins say the unconditioned is form, the Abhidharmists say the unconditioned is formless. Each holding a different view leads to disputes.
I now say whether there is or is not the unconditioned, I will never reckon it as form or formless, let alone each reckoning it differently.
Moreover, I say whether there is or is not the unconditioned, I will never definitely hold that the Hinayana has it and the Mahayana does not, and thus there will be no disputes.

The reason for this is that they mutually appear from one side, not exclusively in one place.
